user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrFromString_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrFromString_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, const char *string)
{
    void *                  addrbuffer;
    OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in.sin_addr;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_addr;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    /* This function is defined as returning 1 on success, not 0 */
    if (inet_pton(Accessor->sa.sa_family, string, addrbuffer) != 1)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_SocketAddrFromString_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
...
#define OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (inet_pton(Accessor->sa.sa_family, string, addrbuffer) != 1)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated — the controlling expression calls inet_pton(...) and compares its runtime return value to 1. inet_pton depends on runtime inputs (the provided string, sa_family and addrbuffer) and so is not invariant. The rule’s exceptions (which concern invariant loop controls) do not need to be applied here.
